document.docAuthor: Eun, Ye, Kim, Young-Hyo, Hendrycks, Ed A. & Lee, Kyung-Sook
document.masterDocTitle: The family Hyalidae (Crustacea: Amphipoda: Talitroidea) from Korean waters. 1. Genus Ptilohyale Bousfield & Hendrycks, 2002

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The family Hyalidae (Crustacea: Amphipoda: Talitroidea) from Korean waters. 1. Genus Ptilohyale Bousfield & Hendrycks, 2002

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Hyale barbicornis
Hiwatari & Kajihara, 1981
: 21
, figs 1–3 . —
Barnard & Karaman, 1991
: 369
. —
Ishimaru, 1994
: 67
.
Allorchestes plumicornis
. —
Iwasa, 1939
: 289
, pl. 22 , figs 25–26 .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined.
5 ♂
, 13 ♀, Maengseon-ri, Wando Is.,
24 may 1998
, (C.M. Lee);
1 ♂
, Dodun-ri, Seocheongun,
20 June 1998
, (C.M. Lee);

, Doma-ri, Namhae-gun,
29 June 1998
, (Y.H. Kim);

, 5 ♀, Chamyeon-ri, Namhae-gun,
29 June 1998
, (Y.H. Kim);

, Gunlae-ri, Dolsando Is.,
30 June 1998
, (Y. Eun);

, (Y.H. Kim);

Kim);

16 February 2012
, (T.S. Park).

Description. Male. Body (
Fig. 5
A) about 13.4 mm long, dorsally smooth.

Head. Head rectangular, as wide as long, shorter than pereonites 1–2 combined; eye comparatively large, elliptical.
Antenna 1
(
Fig. 5
B) shorter than antenna 2 , peduncular articles 1–3 length in ratio of 1 : 0.89 : 0.89 , peduncle slightly longer than half of flagellum, each article with short setae distally; flagellum 12 -articulate, articles 4–12 bearing 2 short aesthetascs.
Antenna 2
(
Fig. 5
C) shorter than 1 / 3 of body length, stouter than antenna 1 ; peduncular article 5 and flagellum articles 1–6 heavily plumose-setose posteriorly; flagellum 12 -articulate.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5 .
Ptilohyale barbicornis
(Hiwatari & Kajihara, 1981)
, male, 13.4 mm, Seodo-ri, Geomundo Is., Korea: A, lateral view; B, antenna 1; C, antenna 2; D, right mandible; E, maxilla 1; F, maxilla 2; G, maxilliped. Scale bars = 1 mm (A–C), 0.5 mm (D–G).

FIGURE 6 .
Ptilohyale barbicornis
(Hiwatari & Kajihara, 1981)
, male, 13.4 mm, Seodo-ri, Geomundo Is., Korea: A, gnathopod 1; B, gnathopod 2; C, pereopod 3; D, pereopod 4; E, pereopod 5; F, pereopod 6; G, pereopod 7. Scale bars = 0.5 mm (A–G).

FIGURE 7.
Ptilohyale barbicornis
(Hiwatari & Kajihara, 1981)
, male, 13.4 mm, Seodo-ri, Geomundo Is., Korea: A, uropod 1; B, uropod 2; C, uropod 3; D, left part of telson; female, 7.3 mm, Seodo-ri, Geomundo Is., Korea: E, gnathopod 1; F, gnathopod 2. Scale bars = 0.5 mm (A–F).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Right mandible (
Fig. 5
D), incisor 7 -dentate; lacinia mobilis with 3 serrate teeth; molar strongly triturative, with 1 pappose seta; 2 accessory spines, 2 plumose setae placed between lacinia mobilis and molar process, with pubescence near molar.
Maxilla 1
(
Fig. 5
E), inner plate slender, apical margin with 2 plumose setae; outer plate stout, apical margin with 8 serrate spine-teeth (may be missing one); palp uniarticulate, with apical simple seta.
Maxilla 2
(
Fig. 5
F), inner plate subequal in length to outer one, with numerous apical setae and mediodistal margin with 1 pectinate seta; outer plate with numerous apical setae. Maxilliped (
Fig. 5
G), inner plate slightly extending beyond half of outer plate, with plumose setae medially, 3 conical teeth and 5 plumose setae apically; outer plate subovate, extending to nearly half of palp article 2 , with row of simple setae medially, slender setiform teeth and simple setae apically; palp broad, 4 -articulate, article 2 broadened, with pinnate setae on inner margin; article 3 broadening distally, apical margins with numerous long setae; article 4 elongate, falcate, inner margin with short setae; unguis slender, acute.

Pereon.
Gnathopod 1
(
Fig. 6
A), coxa roundly produced anteroventrally, posterior marginal cusp prominent; basis broadening distally, posterior margin with 2–3 setae; carpus, subtriangular, long, 0.91 x propodus, carpal lobe rounded, carpus and propodus ventral margins with pectinate setae; propodus subrectangular, length
2 x
width, palm slightly oblique, defined by two spines; dactylus shorter than half of propodus.
Gnathopod 2
(
Fig. 6
B), coxa subquadrate, posterior margin rounded, midposterior marginal cusp prominent; basis with small hydrodynamic lobe anterodistally; carpus short, with elongated carpal lobe; propodus elliptical, longer than
2 x
propodus of gnathopod 1 , palm long and convex, with rows of long spines and setules, palm defined by two spines, ventral margin with small protuberance behind palmar spines; dactylus falcate, 0.66 x propodus, fitting palm.
Pereopod 3
(
Fig. 6
C) slender, coxa similar to coxa 2 ; basis elongate, posterior margin with row of setae; merus anterior margin with 2 spines; propodus rectangular, posterior margin with 1 - 1 - 1 - 1 spine formula; dactylus very short, medial margin with strong seta; length ratio of articles 2–7 = 1.00: 0.37 : 0.73 : 0.55 : 0.55 : 0.20 .
Pereopod 4
(
Fig. 6
D) similar to pereopod 3 .
Pereopod 5
(
Fig. 6
E) as long as pereopod 4 , length ratio of articles 2–7 = 1.00: 0.26 : 0.71 : 0.63 : 0.71 : 0.26 ; coxa bilobate, much broader than long, anterior lobe slightly larger than posterior lobe; basis subovate, broadly expanded, posterior margin with weak notch and surge seta, anteroproximal margin with 3-4 clusters of spines; merus broadening distally, both margins with spines; carpus, posterior margin lacking spines; propodus rectangular, anterior margin with 2–3 clusters of spines; dactylus short.
Pereopod 6
(
Fig. 6
F) longer than pereopod 5 , length ratio of articles 2–7 = 1.00: 0.20 : 0.68 : 0.66 : 0.72 : 0.16 ; coxa shallow, bilobate, anterior lobe small, about 1 /
3 x
width of posterior lobe; basis ovate, anterior margin with row of spines; posterior margin with weak notch and surge seta; merus-propodus longer than pereopod 5 ; dactylus similar to pereopod 5 .
Pereopod 7
(
Fig. 6
G), length ratio of articles 2–7 = 1.00: 0.26 : 0.70 : 0.70 : 0.80 : 0.20 ; coxa small, rounded ventrally; basis subovate, extended posteriorly, slightly serrate, anterior margin with row of spines; merus-propodus longer than pereopod 6 ; dactylus slightly larger than found on pereopod 6 .

Pleon.
Uropod 1
(
Fig. 7
A) peduncle slightly longer than rami, with 5 dorsolateral, 3 dorsomedial and 1 large distomedial spine, which is about 0.37 x inner ramus; inner ramus with 1 dorsal spine and 3 apical spines; outer ramus with 3 dorsal spines and 2–3 apical spines.
Uropod 2
(
Fig. 7
B) about 1 /
3 x
uropod 1 ; peduncle slightly shorter than rami, with 4 dorsolateral and 1 dorsomedial spine; inner ramus subequal in length to outer ramus, with 2 dorsal spines and 4 apical spines; outer ramus with 4 dorsal spines and 3 apical spines.
Uropod 3
(
Fig. 7
C) short, uniramous, about 0.25 x uropod 1 ; peduncle slightly longer than ramus, with 1 dorsal spine; ramus with 7 apical spines, 2 of them long, subequal in length to ramus. Telson (
Fig. 7
D) right lobe lost during dissection, fully bilobate, each lobe with 2 pairs of penicillate setae dorsally.

Pereon.
Gnathopod 1
(
Fig. 7
E), coxa subrectangular, longer than that of male.
Gnathopod 2
(
Fig. 7
F), coxa similar in shape but longer than that of male; basis with small hydrodynamic lobe; carpus with lobe; propodus subrectangular, much less robust than male; brood plate subtriangular, very large, apex subacute, length 2 / 3 times that of basis-propodus combined, with numerous, short marginal brood setae, setae hook-tipped.

Remarks. The following minor morphological differences were found between our material and the Japanese specimens of
Hiwatari & Kajihara ( 1981 )
: 1 ) coxa 1 produced anteroventrally and slightly broadened (vs. not produced); 2 ) gnathopods 1–2 , ventral margin of propodus with small protuberance behind palmar spines (vs. without protuberance), and 3 ) pereopods 3–4 more slender. This species is mostly widespread along the west coast to south coast in Korea , mainly among algae and under cobble.
